header_summary:
Peter Todd raises concerns over the classification of CVE-2017-12842 as a critical vulnerability, questioning the practicality and cost-effectiveness of addressing it through a software fork. His skepticism extends to the impact on projects like Sergio's RSK Bridge contract, highlighting broader issues with project designs and the traditional vulnerability disclosure process within the Bitcoin Core community. Todd suggests that direct publication, as done on his [website](https://petertodd.org), may sometimes be more effective than engaging in potentially politically charged disclosure processes.

Antoine Riard warns of the risks associated with increasing Bitcoin block frequency through timewarping, pointing out the potential for network instability and unhealthy incentives for both users and miners. Despite the allure of lower fees and increased block rewards, Riard emphasizes the importance of prioritizing the network's long-term health over short-term benefits. His discussion also touches on the technical complexities within Bitcoin's development environment, underscoring the ongoing need for developer consensus and clarity.

ZmnSCPxj introduces a novel transaction mechanism called swap-in-potentiam, designed to improve the efficiency of channel openings by allowing third-party funding without the traditional waiting period between onchain confirmation and offchain channel opening. Despite current technical limitations, such as the lack of support for MuSig2 in PSBT, there is optimism for future integration. The draft specification for this mechanism is available [here](https://github.com/ZmnSCPxj-jr/swap-in-potentiam/blob/cf7b11476ee5ad7a85edb5482d05f17ff625feb4/doc/swap-in-potentiam.md), offering insights into its potential to streamline cryptocurrency transactions.

Lastly, discussions led by Harding and Murch delve into transaction fee optimization strategies and the challenges of `OP_EXPIRE` transactions. Harding compares Ephemeral Anchors and Sponsor Transactions, exploring cost-saving methods and the complexities of transaction fee management. Murch emphasizes the importance of high fee rates for the inclusion of `OP_EXPIRE` transactions in blocks, pointing out the consensus on the need for careful management to ensure blockchain efficiency and reliability.

recent_posts.title: Payjoin-in-Potentiam: Externally fund an LSP channel open with one transaction
recent_posts.summary:
- Swap-in-potentiam introduces a novel cryptocurrency transaction method, avoiding traditional swap processes.
- It necessitates all funding transaction inputs come from the same LSP and facilitates watch-only wallets.
- This system allows channels to open with only onchain confirmation, simplifying transactions between parties.

active_posts.title: A Free-Relay Attack Exploiting RBF Rule #6
active_posts.summary:
- RBF Rule 6 incentivizes miners to prioritize transactions with higher fee rates, affecting Bitcoin's economic incentives.
- Replace-by-Fee-Rate (RBFR) limits fee-rate increases to prevent bandwidth exploitation through free-relay attacks.
- Implementing RBFR poses challenges to wallet apps but offers a solution to improve mining economics and reduce attack risks.

active_posts.title: On consensus changes in bitcoin 2024
active_posts.summary:

- The email encourages a discussion on seeking broader consensus in cryptocurrency governance.
